title: Manasa School For The Special Children
detailsOfAchievement: Manasa School For The Special Children Society. Registered under the society act it is purely Non-Profitable organization, the society working for differently abled children those who are needy in the society. We have home based hostel facility and best school activities, both activities are in the same permise. In our service roof we imparting special education, physio therapy, speech therapy, play therapy, occupational therapy and also one small vocational workshop. Our school was recognised by the state government of tamil nadu. In this field group of people contains special educators, social workers, speech and physio therapist,care givers and helpers to take care of the home and school children. Many of our children getting training from our school and put job placement in other shop and companies and few of children studies in main stream education in non formal education way correnspondence courses, with support of manasa few of our staffs educated as a special educators. We privide hygienic food, color uniforms and medical care those who are in our service roof. We provide home based rehabilitation for those who are not able to our centre.

detailsOfAchievement: Multi-Dimensionally Integrated Resourceful Ark known as MIRA Trust is an Indian development organization committed to addressing on the key issues of Health, Education and inequality among the vulnerable sectors of the functioning terrain. Our aim is to make the individual of the society to recognize ones own sources of energy inherent within and then to leverage the external viable resource to make it as a comprehensive apparatus to thrust towards the social change at micro level within the individual and in society at macro level. Every success begins with a Small and Sincere steps initiated by a single person who has innermost perseverance on a specific thrust areas to the welfare of the global cause. MIRA is such a single unit established with the vision to Self Recognition is the Stairway for Sovereignty through the constant handholding support of professionals and well-wishers for the development of our society. Empowering the vulnerable is the eyehole of success for social development. Internalizing the phenomenon the MIRA had charted to work with the following areas of intervention at the field from its launch. Health, Education, Gender equality, Legal Rights, Environment, Life skill, Livelihood, Research, Data collection cum analysis, Technical facilitation services, In and Off campus counseling for students and parents and Networking. The day today living humanity is encircled with numerous facets of vulnerable segment and to categorize the precise and the highly deserving group from the stacks of population is not so trouble free. Moreover to implement the activities among them requires a great deal of determination and teamwork to taste the outcome of our intervention. Educational Environment Enrichment centre were established at 3 blocks of Trichy and Pudukottai districts covering 278 rural children of both sex. Youth development initiatives were taken with 1250 College students. Environmental promotional efforts were taken with 1780 school students. NCD camp was organized for the coastal villages and given guidance for further follow ups Legal literacy camps were organized for the rural women and data collection were also done among the gipsy and nomads group in hands with District legal Aid and directed the participants to access the service at the government. In site and off site counseling for the adolescent students of both sex and their parents are given in hands with matriculation schools in Trichy. About 600 rural and 400 urban households had promoted Kitchen garden on free sets of seeds distributed to the woman of each household in Trichy and Pudukottai districts. Networked with Government, Non Government and industrial sectors for the social development on Disaster management and Tuberculosis. Massive women Health awareness created particularly on Breast cancer. Facilitated key subject areas among vulnerable groups of Adolescent girls, Widows and Children. It is this Milestone of the MIRA on multiple areas of social development projects with the mechanism of numerous hands and minds for their timeless and tireless efforts in planning, organizing and to bring the expected output of these activities at the society, moreover among the vulnerable population.

detailsOfAchievement: The main thrust of the Trust is to foster value system in the society by conducting Carnatic Music Concerts that are accessible for all people to listen to, free of cost. The area of activity is at present confined to the promotion of classical carnatic music with emphasis on its inherent values and traditional excellence. This is sought to be achieved by arranging 4 to 5 concerts every month and a series of concerts(around 60) during the December Music Festival Season. Senior Artists known for their adherence to tradition with impeccable padanthara are invited to present concerts. This also gives an exposure for the upcoming generation of young musicians to understand and emulate them. Young musicians of such a bent of mind are encouraged by giving them greater opportunities all round the year. The constant pursuits of our ideals are being appreciated by the Senior Musicians, who have consistently extended their support by giving performances on this platform. Special mention has to be made of artists like Padma Vibhushan awardee T.N.Krishnan, Padma Bhushan awardee P.S.Narayanaswamy, Sangita Kalanidhis T.K.Govinda Rao, R.Vedavalli, Flute N.Ramani, Doyen Veena Artists the Late Kalpakam Swaminathan, R. Venkatraman besides many others. We feel reasonably proud that our humble contribution by way of exposing the upcoming young musicians to the eternal excellence of our cultural milieu has started yielding results.

detailsOfAchievement: 1. Enabling Government to purchase Copra coconuts from farmers at fair price through NAFED and save numerous farmers lives. 2. On 18th august 2019, Naam has given 5000 saplings for the first set of GAJA cyclone affected farmers. 3. Bringing products directly from the farmers without intervention of traders. 4.NAAM summit for water was conducted for interlinking indian rivers. 5. Claimed compensation for farmers in BT Cotton seeds germination issue. 6. Helped farmers during floods, cyclones.
